pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:0.4: The sub-chapter on evenly all around
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:0.5: 1. The training rule on evenly all around
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:0.6: Venerables, these rules to be trained in come up for recitation.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.2: At that time the monks from the group of six wore their sarongs hanging down in front and behind.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.4: “How can the Sakyan ascetics wear their sarongs hanging down in front and behind? They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.5: The monks heard the complaints of those people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.6: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.7: “How can the monks from the group of six wear their sarongs hanging down in front and behind?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.8: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.9: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks from the group of six:
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.10: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.13: “… Foolish men, how can you do this?
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.14: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.15: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.16.1: ‘“I will wear my sarong evenly all around,” this is how you should train.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.17: One should wear one’s sarong evenly all around, covering the navel and the knees.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.18: If a monk, out of disrespect, wears his sarong hanging down in front or behind, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.26: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk1:1.27: The first training rule is finished.
